utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve been thinking about time travel again.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why, did you hit a roadblock with invisibility?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Put it on the back burner. Anyway, it occurs to me, if I ever did perfect a time machine, I’d just go into the past and give it to myself, thus eliminating the need for me to invent it in the first place.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Interesting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, it really takes the pressure off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sounds like a breakthrough, should I call the science magazines and tell them to hold the front cover?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s time travel, Leonard, I will have already done that.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Then I guess congratulations are in order.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, congratulations will have been in order. You know, I’m not going to enjoy this party.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I know, I’m familiar with you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: At the last department party, Dr Finkleday cornered me and talked about spelunking for 45 minutes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, I was there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know what’s interesting about caves, Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well then we’ll avoid Finkleday, we’ll meet the new department head, congratulate him, shake his hand and go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How’s this? Pleased to meet you, Dr Gablehouser. How fortunate for you that the University has chosen to hire you, despite the fact that you’ve done no original research in 25 years, and instead have written a series of popular books that reduce the great concepts of science to a series of anecdotes, each one dumbed down to accommodate the duration of an average bowel movement. Mahalo.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mahalo’s a nice touch.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do you know there are only eight consonants in the Hawaiian language.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Interesting, you should lead with that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, God, Look at this buffet. I love America.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You don’t have buffets in India?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Of course, but it’s all Indian food. You can’t find a bagel in Mumbai to save your life. Schmear me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well here’s an interesting turn of events.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What. Howard brought a date?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A more plausible explanation is that his work in robotics has made an amazing leap forward.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, what up, science bitches? May I introduce my special lady friend, Summer.

utterance.speaker: Summer
utterance.content: I already told you, touching’s extra.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Right. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (to Sheldon)
utterance.content: Here comes our new boss, be polite.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Hi fellas, Eric Gablehouser.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Howard Wolowitz.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Howard, nice to meet you, and you are?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: An actual real scientist. How was that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t believe he fired me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, you did call him a glorified high-school science teacher whose last successful experiment was lighting his own farts.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In my defence, I prefaced that by saying “with all due respect.”

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Morning

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Morning.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re making eggs for breakfast?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This isn’t breakfast, it’s an experiment.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Huh? Cos it looks a lot like breakfast.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I finally have the time to test my hypothesis, about the separation of the water molecules from the egg proteins, and its impact vis-a-vis taste.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sounds yummy. I look forward to your work with bacon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: As do I.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, I’m sure if you just apologised to Gablehauser he would give you your job back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t want my job back. I’ve spent the last three and a half years staring at greaseboards full of equations. Before that I spent four years working on my thesis. Before that I was in college, and before that, I was in the fifth grade. This is my first day off in decades, and I’m going to savour it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay. I’ll let you get back to fixing your eggs.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not just fixing my eggs, I’m fixing everyone’s eggs.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And we all thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Use new eggs. .

utterance.speaker: Penny (popping her head round)
utterance.content: Hi, hey. I’m running out to the market, do you guys need anything?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, well this would be one of those circumstances that people unfamiliar with the law of large numbers would call a coincidence.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I need eggs. Four dozen should suffice.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Four dozen?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, and evenly distributed amongst brown, white, free range, large, extra-large and jumbo.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, one more time?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Never mind, you won’t get it right, I’d better come with you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, yay!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How come you didn’t go into work today.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m taking a sabbatical, because I won’t kow-tow to mediocre minds.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So you got canned, huh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Theoretical physicists do not get canned. But yeah.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, maybe it’s all for the best, you know I always say, when one door closes, another one opens.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No it doesn’t. Not unless the two doors are connected by relays, or there are motion sensors involved.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, no, I meant…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Or the first door closing causes a change of air pressure that acts upon the second door.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Never mind.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Slow down. Slow down, please slow down.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: We’re fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Look, you’re not leaving yourself enough space between cars.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, sure I am.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no. Let me do the math for you, this car weighs let’s say 4,000lb, now add say 140 for me, 120 for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’m sorry, did I insult you? Is your body mass somehow tied into your self worth?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Interesting. Anyway, that gives us a total weight of, let’s say, 4,400lb.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Let’s say 4,390.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine. We’re travelling forward at, good Lord, 51 miles an hour. Now let’s assume that your brakes are new and the callipers are aligned, still, by the time we come to a stop, we’ll be occupying the same space as that Buick in front of us, an impossibility that nature will quickly resolve into death, mutilation and… oh look, they built a new put-put course.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is great. Look at me, out in the real world of ordinary people, just living their ordinary, colourless, workaday lives.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, thank you. And thank you, ordinary person. Hey, you want to hear an interesting thing about tomatoes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, no, no not really. Listen, didn’t you say you needed some eggs.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uh, yes, but anyone who knows anything about the dynamics of bacterial growth knows to pick up their refrigerated foods on the way out of the supermarket.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, okay, well maybe you should start heading on out then.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, this is fun. Oh, the thing about tomatoes, and I think you’ll really enjoy this, is, they’re shelved with the vegetables, but they’re technically a fruit.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Interesting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, I mean what you find enjoyable.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (as Penny selects vitamin supplements)
utterance.content: Oh boy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, there’s some value to taking a multivitamin, but the human body can only absorb so much, what you’re buying here are the ingredients for very expensive urine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, maybe that’s what I was going for.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well then you’ll want some manganese.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That was fun. Maybe tomorrow we can go to one of those big warehouse stores.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, I don’t know Sheldon, it’s going to take me a while to recover from all the fun I had today.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you sure. There are a lot of advantages to buying in bulk. For example, I noticed that you purchase your tampons one month’s supply at a time.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well think about it, it’s a product that doesn’t spoil, and you’re going to be needing them for at least the next thirty years.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You want me to buy thirty years worth of tampons?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, thirty, thirty five, hey, when did your mother go into menopause?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I’m not talking about this with you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, Penny, this is a natural human process, and we’re talking about statistically significant savings. Now, if you assume 15 tampons per cycle and a 28 day cycle, are you fairly regular? Okay, no warehouse store, but we’re still on for put-put golf, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard (entering)
utterance.content: Hey, I just ran into Penny, she seemed upset about something.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I think it’s her time of the month. I marked the calendar for future reference.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s with the fish?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s an experiment.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What happened to your scrambled egg research?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that was a dead end. Scrambled eggs are as good as they’re ever going to be.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So… fish.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I read an article about Japanese scientists, who inserted DNA from luminous jellyfish into other animals, and I thought hey, fish nightlights.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fish nightlights.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a billion dollar idea. Shhhhh!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mum’s the word. Sheldon, are you sure you don’t want to just apologise to Gablehauser and get your job back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no, no, no. No, I’ve too much to do.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Like luminous fish.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Shhhhh!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right… I didn’t….

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s just the beginning. I also have an idea for a bulk mail-order feminine hygiene company. Oh, glow in the dark tampons! Leonard, we’re going to be rich.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you for coming on such short notice.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You did the right thing calling.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I didn’t know what else to do, he’s lost all focus, every day he’s got a new obsession. This is a particularly disturbing one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (looking round)
utterance.content: Mommy.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Hi baby.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (mouths)
utterance.content: You called my mother?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, you got yourself a loom, how nice.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Honey, why did you get a loom?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was working with luminous fish, and I thought, hey, loom! Mom, what are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Leonard called me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know, but why?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Because one of the great minds of the twenty-first century is raising glow-in-the-dark fish and weaving sarapes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is not a sarape. This is a poncho. A sarape is open at the sides, a poncho is closed, this is a poncho, and neither is a reason to call someone’s mother.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really, when was the last time you left the house.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I went to the market with Penny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That was three weeks ago.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well then buckle up, in the next four to eight days she’s going to get very crabby.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sweetheart, your little friend is concerned about you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, well I’m not a child, I’m a grown man capable of living my life as I see fit. And I certainly don’t need someone telling on me to my mother.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: To my room, and no-one’s allowed in.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: He gets his temper from his daddy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: He’s got my eyes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I see.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: All that science stuff, that comes from Jesus.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon? Your mum made dinner.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (off)
utterance.content: I’m not hungry.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, Leonard, don’t trouble yourself, he’s stubborn. He may stay in there ‘til the Rapture.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are we so sure that’s a bad thing?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I’ll tell ya, I love the boy to death, but he has been difficult since he fell out of me at the K-Mart.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Excuse me for being so bold, but I now see where Sheldon gets his smouldering good looks.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, honey that ain’t going to work, but you keep trying. I made chicken, I hope that isn’t one of the animals that you people think is magic? You know, we have an Indian gentleman at our church, a Dr Patel, it’s a beautiful story, the lord spoke to him, and moved him to give us all 20% off on lasic, you know, those that needed it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That is a lovely story, um, are we going to do anything about Sheldon?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, we will, you have to take your time with Sheldon. His father, God rest his soul, used to say to me, Mary, you have to take your time with Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sounds like a wise man.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, not so wise, he was trying to fight a bobcat for some licquorish. So, everybody grab a plate, and a pretty place mat that Shelly wove.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Has Shelly ever freaked out like this before.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, all the time, I remember one summer when he was thirteen, he built a small nuclear reactor in the shed and told everybody he was going to provide free electricity for the whole town, well the only problem was he had no, whatchacall, fissionable materials. Anyway, when he went on the internets to get some, a man from the government came by and sat him down real gentle and told him it’s against the law to have yellow cake uranium in a shed.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, the poor boy had a fit, locked himself in his room and built a sonic death ray.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: A death ray?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, that’s what he called it, didn’t even slow down the neighbour kids. It pissed our dog off to no end. You know, you two make a cute couple.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, we’re not, we’re not, not a couple, two singles, like those individually wrapped slices of cheese that…. are friends.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Did I pluck a nerve there?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh yeah.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Okay. Alright everybody, it’s time to eat. Oh Lord, we thank you for this meal, all your bounty, and we pray that you help Sheldon get back on his rocker. Now after a moment of silent meditation I’m going to end with “In Jesus’ Name” but you two don’t feel any obligation to join in. Unless, of course, the holy spirit moves you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh my God, this is the best cobbler I’ve ever had.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: It was always Sheldon’ s favourite. You know what the secret ingredient is?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Love?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Lard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, look who’s come out….

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shhh! You’ll spook him. He’s like a baby deer, you gotta let him come to you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This is ridiculous. Dammit, Sheldon, snap out of it. You’re a physicist, you belong at the University doing research, not hiding in your room.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You don’t hunt, do you?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper (entering)
utterance.content: Good morning, snicker-doodle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Morning.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, well that looks awful fancy, what is that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s my idea of what DNA would look like in a silicon based life form.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: But intelligently designed by a creator, right?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What do you want, mom?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You know how your daddy used to say that you can only fish for so long before you got to throw a stick of dynamite in the water?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, I’m done fishing. You put those on.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What for?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Because you’re going to go down to your office, you’re going to apologise to your boss, and get your job back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I’m sorry, did I start that sentence with the words “if it please your highness?”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not going to apologise, I didn’t say anything that wasn’t true.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Now you listen here, I have been telling you since you were four years old, it’s okay to be smarter than everybody but you can’t go around pointing it out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Because people don’t like it. Remember all the ass-kickings you got from the neighbour kids? Now let’s get cracking. Shower, shirt, shoes, and let’s shove off.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wouldn’t have been any ass-kickings if that stupid death ray had worked.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Problem solved.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really? That’s impressive.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Leonard, the Lord never gives us more than we can handle. Thankfully he blessed me with two other children who are dumb as soup.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Excuse me, Dr Gablehouser, are you busy?

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Well, actually….

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sheldon, he’s just doodling, get in here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Dr Gablehouser.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Dr Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Let’s go, baby, we’re losing daylight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Um, as you know, several weeks ago in our first encounter we may have gotten off on the wrong foot, when I called you an idiot. And I just wanted to say that I was wrong. To point it out.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser (to Mrs Cooper)
utterance.content: I’m sorry, we haven’t been introduced. Dr Eric Gablehouser.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Mary Cooper, Sheldon’s mom.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Now that’s impossible, you must have had him when you were a teenager.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, aren’t you sweet, his father’s dead.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Recently?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Long enough.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser (indicating chair)
utterance.content: Please. Sheldon, shouldn’t you be working?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (leaving)
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, how did it go?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I got my job back.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really? What happened?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not quite sure. It involves a part of the human experience that has always eluded me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That narrows it down.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I’m very proud of you honey, you showed a lot of courage today.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thanks, mom. Mom?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Mmm-hmm?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is Dr Gablehouser going to be my new daddy?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: We’ll see. Sleep tight.
